The part you mentioned about thinking heat would be additive in the case of two heat sources where one is hotter than the other- there’s a simple reason why it isn’t…

Heat flows from hot to cold, from source to sink. In this scenario, the less hot heat source is still considered cold, relatively. So it’ll absorb the difference until they both equilibrate out.

Same works the other way around too. Think of how ice cream is made - the cold cream is subjected to a brine slurry that’s even colder, and so the heat flows from the cream into the brine, thereby destabilizing the cream and fat therein to form ice cream.

My two cents:  Pumping liquid hydrogen is a PITA and usually results in lower thrust to weight ratio engines.  This is because liquid hydrogen has about 7% the density of water.  Running LH2 through a centrifugal pump to pressurize it is really hard.  The weight of the engines subtracts from payload capacity, so a poor thrust to weight ratio is a significant problem.  Also, since liquid hydrogen has the density of cotton candy (just kidding), the tanks for it have to be really large.  This all eats away at the benefits of using LOX-LH2 over LOX-Methane or LOX-RP1.

I know this comment is very late, but maybe someone coming to this video will find it enlightening.

The reason you need to expand the flow after the throat is counter-intuitive but comes from an obvious, though little thought about property of compressible flow. Not to sound pedantic, the speed of sound is the speed at which a pressure wave will travel through a medium. Sound is literally just pressure waves and those waves will always travel at the same speed in a medium under specific conditions. The limiting factor that determines the speed of sound/pressure waves is the point at which the flow becomes incompressible, i.e. you literally cannot squeeze it further due to thermodynamic limitations.

What this means is that once the engine exhaust flow goes sonic, it physically cannot be compressed any further, so continuing to reduce throat size beyond that point simply reduces how much mass can be forced through leading to slowdown. You can actually have a throat with some length to it to accommodate varying input pressures and you'll only slightly impact efficiency.


To accelerate the flow to supersonic, you have to expand the pathway to give the gas more room to expand. This causes it to go faster because you're essentially giving space to run out, like popping the cork on a bottle. The actual thermodynamics behind it are far more complicated than this basic view and trust me when I say the math is horrible. You have to combine core thermo principles with PDEs to derive the expansion equations, but it comes out to the same result.

So, rocket nozzles work by squeezing hot gas to an incompressible state, then popping the cork so it can blast out.

Great video. In answer to your comment about not understanding thermo intuitively, imagine you have a house with 10 airtight rooms. In each room, you have a slightly different temperature and pressure. In room 1 for example, 1 atm pressure, 70 degrees, in room 2 1.05 atm 68 degrees, etc. At a certain time you open all the internal doors. This was an actual question in my freshman engineering long ago. The relationship with pressure is not linear, but clearly your house doesn't go to 10atm and 700 degrees, that's absurd (and which some students always answer). There is a total amount of mass, and a total amount of energy, and while I'm sure it's a complex nonlinear relationship we looked up on a graph, at least the temperature and pressure will be somewhere around the average.

Why do we have to use super-hot fuel/exhaust for an aerospike rocket? We have things such as cold-gas thrusters which use hyper-chilled liquid propellants. There's also steam, which wouldn't be hot enough to melt your system down, and could be produced by reacting hydrogen peroxide with a catalyst. I think the reason that aerospike engines haven't gotten very far is the fact that the people working on them are stuck with the concept of needing a super-efficient super-hot exhausts at all altitudes. If we tone back the expectations and use aerospikes for something other than SSTO systems, they could prove much more advantageous than expected.

There is one case where an aerospike makes sense: powered descent.

If you need to use your engines to land in an atmosphere, it makes sense from a weight perspective to deal with that. Starship plans to get around this by having two sets of engines: one set for orbital propulsion and one set for landing. While that works, if you could make an engine of equivalent weight that does both, it'd be theoretically good.

The only topic I think we skipped or glazed over is that; if you have a dual stage bell nozzle design rocket, with engines optimized for their environment at each stage compared to an SSTO Aerospike; how do they compare in weight and performance for the overall rocket?

I'm assuming it got swept into the REASONING for why we said they have the same performance, but I feel it's an interesting thing to get into, as far as "why".

For a multi stage rocket, there is added complexity in decoupling the 2 stages, the weight of not just the first, but second stage rockets, the supplementary equipment for both stages, etc to run both the sea level optimized rocket, AND the Vacuum optimized rocket stages. Is the Aerospike engine heavier than engines placed in both stages?

What are the weight savings of running 1 single rocket as opposed to running several stages worth of bell nozzles?

Big picture here: if you have an SSTO engine, it can be as heavy as 2 stages worth of engines, and break even, so are they (more or less) twice as heavy? Same can be said of the fuel supply and delivery components with gimbling: do they exceed the weight of traditional bell rockets?

I assume they do, because this sort of thing would have been discussed by engineers, but it's the one piece I wish was added to the video.

The requirement would be the settling of water temperature at the point of insertion to just at boiling temperature, so it can evaporate and add at least it's own weight in thrust. Hello Mrs. Randall,
I am watching the section on how Rocket Engines work (Time-stamp 6:27) and I started to think about a problem that the video discusses around 11:00.

Rockets need a lot of pressure to lift off and escape the atmosphere. The best rocket engine to date is the Merlin engines on the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket that produce a big more than 1.7 million lbs of thrust. That is like placing a modern car on to a mail stamp. The reason for engines being as large as they are is because of how fluid gas flow changes as atmospheric pressure drops the higher the rocket travels. The problem arises when a rocket engines bell shape is not properly optimized for the altitude. The bell can be underexpaned at higher altitudes and over expanded at lower altitudes.

(All of this was explained in the video I’m just trying to explain how I reasoned through this)

Could this problem be solved similarly to how a F-16 fighter jet controls its gas flow? By constricting or opening the bell mechanically. I don’t see many rockets with this sort of mechanism and I wonder why they haven’t experimented with a rocket engine that changes shape as it travels higher. I assume the mechanics to changing the shape may be overly heavy, but what if we had a pressurized container that lies around the engine. The gas inside, as it gains altitude, will expand, as well as, the heat of the engine would continue to expand the volume of gas. The purpose for this expansion would be to increase pressure on the engines outer shell to move the theoretical parts of the engine bell that contract or expand the bella radius. Think of the F-16 jet engines and how they have flaps. If you push them all equally, they fold in on them selves, and if you let them go they will be pushed out wards.

Obviously this would need more details but Im thinking there could be regulatory valves that release excess gas to release pressure as needed. Specifically, calculate to be over pressurized as you climb altitude and relieve pressure with the help of AI controllers. A problem with my logic maybe is that the pressure on the inside of the bell may be greater than a outer force from gas resulting in the bell not constricting. Before reaching a vacuum, I think the pressurized casing would have to be completely depleted of its gas so as not to explode.

Thoughts?

Why one would want a single stage rocket? The main reason of multiple stages is not the engine. It's a simple optimization of the fundamental Tsiolkovsky equation. A rocket (with whatever futuristic engine) uses its own mass to propel, it means in the beginning the thrust is mostly wasted to move the fuel, not the payload. As the result the ratio of the mass of the payload to the rocket mass in the beginning is under logarithm. By throwing away the extra mass of the first stage, you exponentially increase the effectiveness of the second stage. In other words, a single stage rocket is exponentially ineffective, regardless of engine.

My favorite answer was the difference between the Physics, and the Engineering. The physicists have a Theory, write it down, and send it to the Engineers: "Make this Work."

"We'll try." Quite often, it requires materials that don't exist, and theoretically can't exist. I'm not willing to write off an Aerospike, but I believe it's that damned Square Cube Law. The problem is, they're trying to make a big one. That works on Parabolic Nozzles, but against a Large Aerospike engine. I would think that something like an Afterburner, in something like the SR-71. An anti-satellite Missile. That's the scale where the numbers might work, but Venture Star was where the numbers multiplied, exponentially for Weight, and Heating. Going Linear minimized that a little bit, but not that much. AND they tried to cram the entire STS into the same faring, which probably wasn't going to work either. Let's take a heavier, less efficient engine, and carry the tanks. (You know the fuel tank the Orbiter could almost fit in?) through the entire flight plan, without external boosters?

"Make it work."

"No. It's not going to work. Go back to the drawing board, and bring us something we can actually do." Venture Star was a commercial, for a cartoon. At the time, (I was working for G.E.) we called it the "Flying Anvil Project."

Depending on the application, but an aerospike is theoretically more efficient for more applications.  Parabolic nozzles are generally better for Vacuum, while Aerospikes are very, VERY heavy.  So, for launchers, you basically have to take out stages to make up that weight.  That's where they have the potential to really eclipse parabolic nozzles:  Removing engines from the full stack.  Fewer engines (And tanks for each stage) is better.  Ideally, we would love to fly 1 engine from surface to orbit.  However, surface to orbit is not the only application.  That's only about 100 miles.  Space is much bigger than that.  For interplanetary, Electric engines will probably be the most Mass Efficient.

Just a quick correction when you were making the analogy of specific impulse to a car's fuel economy. When converting to a metric version of miles per gallon, you used kilometers per litre/liter. Technically that's correct, but it's not what we (I'm a canadian) actually use to determine fuel economy. We actually use liters per 100 kilometers, which is actually a much more useful measurement, making it easier to go "oh ok I need this many liters to go this far." So in that case it's actually better to have a LOWER L/100km, instead of a HIGHER MPG. Great video, I just wanted to be nitpicky and make a comment about it, also it boosts engagement

Why not combine an ablative cone and throat with the Aerospike engine.  Get the pumps and other complex parts for reuse.  Then have the throats and spikes/cones that are ablative and designed for one use.  Combine this with an SSO and then you are replacing the part with the highest thermal load.   Then more ceramics and other high temperature non metallic coating could be employed.  Thus NASA would move from multistage rockets to a reusable SSO.
As an aside, Jerry Pournelle considered the RL-10 (the original one) to be the best rocket engine ever, because Pratt & Whitney didn't know how to make an engine that wasn't reusable.

There is a fundamental problem with trying to do research based on observed behaviors alone. You need a working model at the level of the physical mechanisms so that you target manipulating the actual causes of the physical actions, not targeting the observed factors that correlate to the behaviors you seek.
With aerospike, you are approaching the tech Viktor Schauberger pioneered, using the boundary layer effects to control the flow of your fluids. But only at the tail end after restricting your degrees of freedom beyond the flexibiloty to meet the full requirements of your design. Remember water has a gas energy state that is diamagnetic and can constantly accelerate the speed of gas flow well beyond supersonic without heating any surfaces if you use the water to contain and guide the flow. Viktor did much smaller units that put so much energy in his hydrocarbon-water fuels that they fissioned between copper plates without melting them. I recommend 400 grade stainless for better magnetic field effect. The plasma reactions also generate electromagnetic waves that push off the gravity of the planet, increasing thrust and reducing weight. Party on dudes, be good to each other. Paul Pantone stumbled on the same effects. With a simpler design that may be harder to adapt to rocketry, but give perspective on the operational details that Schauberger 's flight research concealed due to the politics of WWII. See Viktor's 1940 patent app. Pantone's ebook "The book of GEET: Part 1".

So, I see the usefulness of linear aerospikes, as the geometry is significantly simpler. Toroids are a pain to work with. I'm wondering, however, if there's a good reason beyond manufacturing/materials that the tested linear aerospike has a bunch of tiny combustion chambers instead of a few larger rectangular ones. That's certainly not helping the square-cube law because it's adding throat perimeter per chamber volume.

The expansion phase cooling is a no-brainer, though effectively cooling without triggering a pahse change before expansion is not a simple task and an easy failure mode. On the flip side, using the gas expansion to run the compressor instead of burming fuel brings an idea that we could avoid a preburn entirely, and perhaps even return to a single-axis compressor on the ready-to-go fuel-oxidizer mixture. On the other hand, I don't know that heated methalox gasses mixing outside a combustion chamber is a good idea. As for the compressor/turbine, I'm always a sucker for tesla's centripetal ones, mostly because of their conceptual simplicity. Whether they can reach their claimed efficiencies in this scenario is questionable.

It feels, basically, that with the right tweaking, we should be able to get a linear aerospike to function in cross-section, from a thermodynamics standpoint, and then it can be "extruded" to whatever size needed.

Hmm, methinks our aerospike designers may have missed a trick...  If they channeled outside air into and around the engine via aerodynamic intakes, perhaps with a compressor and a reaction engines pre-cooler, this could cool the engines externally and internally during in-atmospheric flight.  Outside the atmosphere the engine could be throttled back enough to prevent overheating but because it is so much more efficient in a vacuum, you don't require all of the power of the engine to get good efficiency.  In space, you can then reserve, say 25%, of engine power for short emergency course correction bursts when needed.

I think long term, (not quite here) SSTOs would be better. Furthering the analogy that it wouldn't make sense to destroy an airplane after each flight (thus Space-X re-useable concept is happening), it also would not make sense to design an airplane that splits in half mid-flight to fire a different set of engines, which greatly increases the complexity and number of failure points. Perhaps with better heat-resistant materials or other designs to simplify the complexity, aerospike engines could be more practical. After Space-X made an 'impossible' full flow nozzle engine,  I think exploring various rocket engine designs is a good idea.

I see quite a lot of mistakes while explaining the nozzle. Of course I don't blame you since for understanding them you need to know thermodynamics and fluid equations. First, when you choke a hose, what will happen is that the flow is going to decrease, since the water needs more energy to get over it. If you are chocking it just a little bit, there will be no difference, but if you get further, this effect will be clear.
In the case of a nozzle it's not the same but quite similar, if you decrease the throat, you will be decreasing the flow, no matter how you do it. The point you got is quite right, you want as much velocity as you can.
Second poit you missed was the shockwaves. While studying a nozzle you need to know where the shockwave is, and it is certainly very important, probably the most important thing.
And finally, when you said that flow is constant, it can get constant but not changing the throat size, but changing the pressure inside (or outside) the chamber. Basically, once the flow gets mach 1 in the throat, the mass flow will be constant for the same throat size no matter the inside or outside conditions (pressure, temperature).

This was interesting!!! I was involved with a rocket engine testing program about 11 years ago (2008-2009) at the AFRL at Edwards Air Force Base... There were several types of engines there... There was an Aerospike Linear engine on Display in the museum area there at the Air Force Research Laboratories...  From what I recall , the original specification of that Aerospike engine, was to be used with the re-usable orbiters which was called the X-33 program... The single stage orbiter, was to achieve an orbit with the Linear Aerospike engine.... The Linear Aerospike engine was to power the winged air/space craft into space from the Earth. And the Aerospike, then would have good performance in the atmosphere AND in the vacuum of space...  If I remember correctly, the X-33 was to have 2 linear Aerospike engines... The thrust was was to be vectored by varying the amount of thrust from the individual propulsion units along the upper part of the ramp where they were located... Therefore, no gimbaling was needed for ACS / RCS... It would simplify the design of the reusable orbiter, and save weight without the use of gimbaling controls (that were necessary with each bell-type rocket engine)....One of the most interesting things about The AFRL at EAFB, is they had complete testing facilities for testing rocket engines & motors that operated in the vacuum that space has... TSRM-Third Stage Rocket Motor testing facilities were very interesting.... It is too bad that the X-33 program was scrapped... There were other programs that were very interesting as well. Hopefully , someday somebody will be able to get these ingenious ideas back into space, where they belong...

haha, at 22:30, yah you don't add the temps. It has to do with energy being taken from the higher energy form, and being put into the lower energy form. That is why you get an average temp, and not a "total added together" temp. It has to with law of conservation of energy pretty sure. This answer is not an exact answer to this phenomena, just a basic overview.

The lower temp material could only get as hot as the higher temp material. So like you say 1000 degrees up to 2500, the 1000 degrees item could only get as hot as the 2500 item. I don't think you could make the 1000 degrees item get hotter than 2500 but maybe. That may violate the law of cons. of energy, and maybe someone else could elaborate on this or provide a more correct answer. But when you do thermo problems, you usually do the average temps to make the problems easier to solve and simulate etc. So you get temp and pressure to get your thermophysical properties of the material/fluid and go from there to make it easier.

This concept is actually really easy to understand, I am just blanking on an explanation for it right now. But I also need to revisit this concept. It is like when you are cooling something. The hotter temp fluid will only get as cold as the lower temp fluid. But both fluids will change temp in the end, unless there is more of one fluid than the other. Then the mixture will either get the hottest temp initially, or coldest temp initially, or in between. But it would depend on how much of the fluids you have; the temp would be based off of that. So it is easier to make it an average. But where it counts, it is definitely not set as an average. There are calculations based on enthalpy that show the temp wont be an average temp, and things will barely heat up or barely cool. All based on the heat transfer coefficient "h." This is pretty in depth, but not that hard really. It can be pretty confusing though.

I think the biggest problem with aerospikes is that staging is too efficient for aerospikes to matter. SpaceX has sea level optimized engines that launch from sea level, detach from the upper stage, and again land at sea level, and vacuum optimized engines that operate only in vacuum. Both are better in their respective regimes than an aerospike which is theoretically a good compromise between sea level efficiency and vacuum. An aerospike carrying a big empty fuel tank is still less efficient than a bell engine not carrying that tank.
For a moment I though an aerospike might be good as a reusable upper stage, because it needs to work in a vacuum, and then come down to sea level to land, but landing is extremely fuel efficient. Most of the deceleration should be done by the atmosphere either way, so overall system efficiency on ascent is far more important than on descent.
Landing an SSTO is also going to be much more difficult than landing just an upper stage. A smaller object takes less shielding to survive unpowered re-entry, or less fuel if you decelerate with engines rather than aerobraking.
Maybe an aerospike can be made that is better than a bell nozzle for some applications, I think it is worth a small portion of our overall space budget to keep looking into. And even if it doesn't work out, the technologies developed may also apply to other kinds of rockets.

@Everyday Astronaut or anyone who has a thought on this. If bell nozzles are optimized for one specific altitude and pressure but aerospikes maintain their efficiency at any altitude, why wouldn't it be a good idea to use aerospikes on a multistage rocket given that bell nozzles still lose efficiency within a single stage? The most common argument I hear against aerospikes is the idea that they don't make a single stage to orbit rocket feasible enough because an STO would still be carrying dead weight but that's more of a critique of STO's than aerospikes. I understand that aerospikes were designed with STO rockets in mind but I keep in mind that bell nozzles still lose efficiency within a single stage at different altitudes, where aerospikes wouldn't.

For example, when we look at the Saturn 5 launches, it's clear that the exhaust was going straight down at sea level but before the first stage was ejected we can see that the exhaust is more spread out in a fan shape and therefore much less efficient. Assuming they were available at the time If the first stage of the Saturn 5 contained aerospikes that wouldn't have happened and they still could have shed the dead weight by ejecting the first stage as they normally would have. I'm not sure this would overcome other disadvantages of aerospikes but I've never heard anyone ask this question.

As for thermodynamics: Air, in physics terms, is also just a liquid. When you have a 100 Celsius degree hot cup of water and mix it with another cup of water that's 50 degrees Celsius, the molecules of those two cups of water mix. Since temperature really is just a measure of how quickly the atoms are moving around, the slower-moving molecules of the relatively colder water will absorb some of the energy of the faster-moving ones of the boiling water. In other words, those molecules will be slowed down and the temperature of the mix will, all things being equal, be around 75 degrees celsius. One quick note: I really was never good at physics in high school. In fact, I utterly failed at it with some exceptions. What really helped me get a better handle on this have been science shows like these on YouTube and other outlets. While I am not very good at complex equations, I am good at understanding through visuals and connections which then help me understand at least some of the math. Back in high school I almost had to repeat a year because I was failing math. My mom found me a tutor who at the time was an art student in college. He was able to intuitively explain to me wave functions (things like f(x)=), "Kurvenanalyse") by showing me how the equations related to the visual representation of those functions. Not only did I pass math, but I went from an F to an A within just a few months. It really felt great and I stopped feeling like a failure when it came to math. I am still very much grateful.

Regarding the non-intuitiveness of the fact, that the high-speed gas has low pressure: yes, it is counter-intuitive, however we can all make an experiment at home. Try this. Take two sheets of paper and hold them close to each other. One in each hand, hanging vertically, maybe 5-10cm or 2-4 inches apart. Now take a deep breath, and blow the air between them for a few seconds.
Basically, you have a rocket engine - inside your lungs/mouth you have a high pressure, but you have a small opening in your lips, so it forces the air out faster.
Now what you can see is the two sheets of paper going towards each other, which means there is a lower pressuee between them than on the outside.
Bernoulli principle at its finest

Safety and simplicity with reusable parts is 100% the critical factor.  The space shuttle ideas, a launch every 2 weeks, with reentry advantages to reuse the same gear, turned out to be 3 months+ per flight, rebuilding the whole thing to check a part had not failed etc. made the cost ridiculous compared to simple, staged rockets with reusable boosters with zero upside. “Your dumb brain” is thinking kind of correctly but it’s confusing heat and temperature.  Heat sums but temperature averages.  Temperature is heat per volume.  If you add heat but keep the volume the same you get a higher temperature.  But when the volume increases at the same time that you add heat then the temperature might not rise. It might even decrease.  When that high temperature exhaust is added to that even higher temperature exhaust it is indeed adding heat but it’s also adding volume and the volume it’s adding is more significant so it actually lowers the combined temperature.

First of all, as usual, I really want to thank you for this really interesting documentary. I can really see all the effort you used to produce it.

That said, as a space engineer, I have to point out some inaccuracies.
-talking about traditional bell engines, bigger engines are easier to cool down not because they use more fuel. Burning more fuel means more heat to dissipate and this will not cool down the engine faster. Actually, its not the absolute amount of fuel that helps to cool down the engine, but its quantity compared with the amount of oxidant. If you inject a rich mixture into the reaction chamber, some fuel will not burn because of the lack of oxidant and will simply evaporate, consuming heat in the process (latent heat). This procedure is really common in every thermal engine because a lot of the thermal energy is not lost, but it is used to further increase pressure in the combustion chamber (fuel increase its volume by a lot while becoming gas from liquid). It does not depend on the actual size of the engine, but only on settings. Actually, the bigger the engine, the more fuel you have to spend to have the same cooling effect.
The real reason bigger engines are easier to cool down is because... they are bigger. Bigger means more mass and this more thermal inertia, more resistance to stress, more space where to install devices that helps you to cool down your engine and bigger radiating surfaces (which are not a downside, as it seems you're saying) and so on.

-and here it comes to aerospike engines. Again: it is true that they have a problem with their cooling down, but that's not because of the wider surface area. There are two problems with cooling down aerospike engines: they need to be really compact and regenerative cooling is not practical if even possible. The first problem is really easy to understand: just look at their design. Packing many combustion chambers near each other, greatly reduce their cooling efficiency. That's the reason we invented V and boxer engines.
The second problem is, again, a problem that comes with the design itself. The idea of regenerative cooling is that you bring the excess heat from the combustion chamber to the nozzle bell where the gas are cooling down naturally because they are expanding. This heat is not completely lost in the process, but it is partially converted into speed in the process and thus the name "regenerative". This is obtained by circulating fuel into the walls of the combustion chamber and then into the walls of the nozzle bell and back. This is of course almost impossible in aerospike engines because they do not have a proper bell where to transfer heat to the expanding gases.

-at last, while talking about thrust to weight ratio, its true that they are way more complex than "traditional" rockets and weigh more., but you also have to say that the idea is to reduce the number of stages required to reach the orbit and this will definitely compensate this increase in engine's weight.

There is also one problem that comes with aerospike engines that I could not hear in your video. this is actually a major problem and I think (but to be honest, i'm not sure) this is even more important that the cooling down problem. Aerospike efficiency is related to the shape of the spike. This is the same problem they had with the SR-71 air intake. Basically, to reach the theoretical maximum efficiency, the spike needs to be infinitely long. Even drawing a finite spike with real dimensions, a really sharp edge is still a problem because it is a weak point unable to resist the temperatures and forces that affect it and it also increase total mass. That's why they "cut" the edge and then they try to overcome the loss in efficiency by using exhaust gasses, as you pointed out.

In the end, the real reason why they are not using aerospike engines is the same reason they still use 60 years old CPUs: reliability. When you spend years in planning a space mission that cost you half a billion dollars and that will bring a few people in the most hostile environment we ever met, you want to be 100% sure your equipment will not fail. As you pointed out, aerospike engines are not tested in vacuum, they have a lot of unsolved problems and they are still a young technology. Since the cold war is over and commercial applications will be really limited, no one will spend billions and billions just to test them. hopefully this will change in the future.

Please, let me say just one more thing, not as a space engineer, but as a "science enthusiast". I really can't understand how can you be so passionate about space and rocketry and so on (and your videos are the proof of this passion) and, at the same time, being so "pessimistic" about new technologies. A piece of technology is just like a person: it born, it grows up, usually it give birth to a new generation of technology and it dies. SSTOs, aerospikes and so on, are just like babies right now. We didn't even start to scratch the surface: it's just like looking at a baby and saying: "oh, he's so useless, he can't even talk. Just dispose of it as a waste". Science does not works like that. Yes, they are useless right now, no one will argue that. But they are the future. And even if you will be proven right and aerospike will be scratched and considered useless junk, the experience we're acquiring right now while studying them is invaluable. As Edison said: "I have not failed. I've just found 10,000 ways that won't work."

A point on the viability of aerospikes, if the benefits were that big, other options might still be better.

For one, you could spend the money creating a ginormous plane powerful enough to lift a large rocket, to lift it above a large amount of the atmosphere, which would give you most of the same advantages, plus extra ones: less atmospheric drag, a few hundred extra m/s of Delta v, better launch angle, much larger freedom to pick launch site/inclination. And again, you can start with a much more expanded nozzle.

Heck just siting your launch platform at high altitude would allow you to take advantage of a larger nozzle expansion, yet I see no one trying to seriously create such a launchpad.

The fact that even that even the latter is considered not worth the hassle, Is fairly damning for the prospects of an aerospike

There's a very easy way to think about combining temperatures of two different objects in thermodynamics:
First off, "cold" is not a quantitative measurement, it's a relative measurement between two temperatures. -50 is colder than +20, and 2500c is colder than 5000c, but "cold" is not a physical property, there is only heat.

So with that in mind, the idea is simple; Hold an ice cube in your hand. The ice cube itself contains a pretty substantial amount of heat (remember, COLD isn't a property), around 255 kelvin. Your hand is around 306k.
When you hold the ice cube, it melts, and your hand gets cold. You add heat to it, and it takes heat from your hand, the temperature is equalizing.
If temperatures combined as a sum, the ice cube would set your hand on fire!

The similarities between rocket nozzle design and 2 Stroke expansion chamber design are amazing.  The expansion chamber divergent cone is designed to create a relative vacuum which pulls remaining exhaust and fresh unburnt charge through the combustion chamber and then into the exhaust.   Then the exhaust utilizes a convergent cone to control the shock wave and pressure spikes to force the unburnt fuel that was pulled into the exhaust back into the combustion chamber, thus pressurizing the chamber before the piston closes the port.  It's a controlled flow separation that gives a 2 stroke engine a literal boost usually in the range of 6-10 PSI.  4 stroke engines need to use turbo chargers or super chargers for the same effect.   Next time you see an expansion chamber on a 2 stroke dirt bike think about the similarities between it and a rocket nozzle!

Everyday astronaut??? Are you an astronaut? I'm kinda confused. Good vid, though, from an EE who knows "not much" about rocket propulsion, meaning much more than the typical layman, MUCH less than, say, my brother, who was a thermal/propulsion guy (strange combo, yeah, but the job "required" it...heard about the aerospike first time from him about 20 odd years ago.

How much force the atmosphere apply?...no secret....about 14.7 lb/sq in. at sea level. What that essentially means is if you took a one inch square tube and projected it it "into space", the atmosphere inside that very narrow tube would actually WEIGH 14.7 lbs.

Think about taking a 10lb and a 5lb weight at the gym, putting them on top off a one inch square block (fairly large gaming dice, like at a casino) and setting them on the back of your hand (say). It would not be even remotely comfortable, actually fairly to quite painful in a short time.

Why don't we experience this pain from the atmosphere? Because it "presses down" both externally and internally in our bodies. By the way, if you quickly REMOVE that force, ie. step into a vacuum, it would be EXCRUCIATINGLY painful.

 I used to put my hand (NEVER anything else, there are horrific horror stories of kids sitting on them, and them removing their ENTIRE intestines, safer redesigns because of that, back when) over the skimmer inlet pipe in the pool circulation/filtering system while trying to get it primed, draining the last of a near empty pool when it lost prime, with a hose running into the skimmer.

You couldn't let air enter the system or it wouldn't pump from "way down there", takes a tremendous amount of vacuum to do that, about 1/3 the atmospheric pressure removed, and a pool pump is a REALLY lousy air pump, it would NEVER get there with much air (other than small bubbles) in the system.

What is ACTUALLY lifting that 10' column of water is the differential pressure above and below the column...the high side IS the atmospheric pressure, and in a big enough pipe, you could lift TONS of water (actually millions of tons, theoretically, practically infinite) by atmospheric pressure alone, to about 30 feet and a bit, at sea level, less on top of a tall mountain. Trees lift it MUCH further (some 450 feet, through capillary action. This is left as an exercise for the "student". Enough of the science lesson. Hope somebody enjoyed this and maybe learned something interesting, and it certainly applies to the video, if in maybe a secondary way, worst case. I think this is all accurate, but look it up if you want to make sure. ;-)

There seems to be a basic problem of everything that accounts for the atmosphere, well you are only really heavily interacting with the atmosphere for a very small percentage of the flight. Most of a first stage even there are no proven or even theoretical techniques promoted forward as a good idea to utilize the air to improve rocket performance by a significant degree. At this the falcon 9 does the best thing possible which is to use a circle of engines to promote the thrust of the inner area. The Super Heavy will have more rings of engines inside this pressure zone on assent. That is really kind of it. Then there is the whole thing where a typical two stage to orbit rocket as Elon Musk has said for every 5 lbs of recovery hardware on the first stage, the payload mass drops by 1lbs. However on the second stage it is a 1 to 1 ratio. This also suggests any small improvements on the first stage efficiency are going to have an even smaller effect on the overall payload mass to orbit.

Something else you don't seem to really touch on is the mass of the fuel tanks, especially when you are talking about LOX/LH2 engines and comparing them against LOX/LNG engines. The total delta-V of a rocket is its ISP times a partial integration between the starting mass and ending mass after burning up the fuel. LH2 is not very dense at least compared to LNG and so an LH2 rocket is going to have a larger ending mass due to the larger tanks. This whole starting to ending mass partial integration times ISP issue is the main reason for multi-stage rockets in the first place as in part way up and after most of the fuel mass is burned up, you chuck off the empty fuel tank mass and associated excess engine mass and basically start a new partial integration with the second stage. This is also why the Space Shuttle sucked as it hauled a giant LH2 tank and a giant orbiter all the way up to orbital speed, which is just madness along with all of the other crazy and unsafe things they did to make the Space Shuttle work at all. LH2 engines have also been plagued by lower thrust than any other type of engine and thrust is important when talking about getting off of Earth as either you have a longer hang time, meaning more delta-V to do the same job or the rocket is just too heavy to get off of the ground or very wide, which has its own disadvantages.

Rocket engine builders never ask electrical engineers, when they should. Cooling large surface areas made from metals at high temperatures, pressure and gas flow rates is a quite hard and expensive job. The better way is to avoid physical contact between gas and metal. No, this isn't a joke. There is something called Lorentz force. In differential form it is dF = dq·(E + v x B). Since metal is conductive, hot gas is conductive too, since it is in an ionized state and coincidently velocity of gas flow realative to the nozzle is high, a very simple an realiable (!) current source (B~I) can do the job to insert a sheet of void. All nasty problems of contact heating vanish, while radiation heating is a Kindergarten to handle. Magnetohydrodynamics is the discipline that rules all parameters in such a setup. Ironically, the opposite job to accelerate hot gas in an ion engine is much harder to perform and thrust is in the mN-range.

Can we do a follow-up on this video to explore OTHER altitude-compensating nozzles? As in, is there anything better than a bell nozzle?
My favorite is the step nozzle, where you basically have a narrow bell nozzle optimized for sea level, then the nozzle takes a sharp step outwards into a bigger bell nozzle optimized for vacuum.
Don't really need to worry about cooling because by the time you get to the vacuum optimized section the exhaust has cooled to the point that you can do purely radiative cooling like the Merlin-1D Vac nozzle extension.

Aerospikes conveniently trap the heat into an enclosed area.  The only direction the heat can radiate away is up through the bottom of the rocket.  Unless we get some exotic materials designed that can passively handle it, it's just not going to happen.  A bell nozzle generates heat on a surface that can radiate it away naturally.  It's the difference between putting a heatsink on top of a CPU vs trying to put one inside of it.  Passive cooling is far more valuable than passive vectoring of the flow.

I think we'll see aerospike as a norm in a distant future, when materials are marvelous, manufacturing techniques are near perfect, and the main goal of any engine is flexibility. There is no need for them now

Also the Wankel engine has pressure ratio issues as you cannot use nice simple circular piston rings. Look at the video at 56:59 and you can see the sharp edge that needs to be closed between the rotating "piston" and the cylinder side wall edge. The engineering limitations this causes limits the pressure ratios and thus fuel efficiency.
The best engine is a field propulsion engine, but since our common understanding of gravity and inertia is mediocre, it's not coming soon....

All the problems of the aerospike are engineering challenges and can be overcome by engineers. The problem is that normal bell-nozzle engines have been continuously optimized for the last 70 years. It's pretty hard to catch up to that. The potential efficiency gain from using them is only a few percent, assuming that SpaceX's Starship design works out with full reusability. It is probably just not worth it to develop the aerospike to the same level of efficiency as the traditional engine.

This is similer to the idea of making Thorium reactors. There is a potential gain, but the cost of overcoming all that has been learned of Uranium reactors makes them impractical. It is better to use the same engineering resources to develop fusion reactors.

The main problem with combustion based propulsion is fuel, same as on earth, you're only going to go as far as the amount of fuel you can carry. In space you can take advantage of gravity wells, sort of the same principle of coasting downhill on terra firma, but distance and speed rely on how steep or how long the hill is. But to get back up the hill you'll still need fuel. About the only technological improvement is to squeeze as much efficiency out of the combustion process as you can, then build a string of refueling stations between your origin and your destination. Perhaps the prospect of exploiting resources available throughout the solar system will drive entrepreneurs to build a network of refueling stations, and vehicles to transport materials back to earth, the moon, or Mars. So as far as aerospike vs a basic nozzle technology is economic, it doesn't really add efficiency, more complicated, and still requires development.
What we really need is an entirely new engine technology that makes all current engines absolete.

It seems like the only way an aerospike would truly be viable is on a huge rocket where each 'small' combustion chamber is actually a whole engine. On Superheavy, for instance, the outer rings of engines could be moved outward, upward, and aimed toward the center with a spike surrounding the 7 gimbaling engines. It wouldn't be a huge increase in expansion ratio, but could make a virtual nozzle the size of the entire base of the booster.

I think Beck gave you the real answer! Cooling the center spike is hard and heavy and dealing with the multiple small combustion chambers is really complex or gives you a big weird donut shaped combustion chamber. But what if you had a ring of rockets engines around a center engine instead and used the thrust interactions to make a virtual aerospike. SpaceX is also using engine plumes as a virtual heat sheild on their reentry burns!

Check out the ARMR project being pursued by the Air Force Research Laboratory. Here is the description: ARMR: The Affordable Responsive Modular Rocket (ARMR) engine architecture presents a paradigm shift in new liquid engine development. This architecture employs many small-scale modular components to replace traditional large-scale engine components, allowing faster development, reducing testing costs, and minimizing risk. By using Additive Manufacturing (AM) technology, small complex components can be rapidly fabricated and tested in low-cost test facilities to provide statistical reliability.

The AS requirement is best suited primarily for military applications which is why Lockheed was so focused on the RS2200 despite other options being jist as viable.

The point of the Aerospike is to reduce the over all vehicle complexity entirely, by trading some powerplant complexity in the process. A single engine for the entire flight regime is a major requirement for any military application that requires an SSTO capable vehicle that can be deployed as a military asset; and that includes deployment in the form of 'scrambles' or intercepts, immidiate requirement for recon due to a battle field developement, or a retaliatory strike package in responds to a enemy's movement or action. The Aerospike is the one place to go for extreme high performance military applications, bar none. Its why the military focuses on such complex engines in fighter crafts. They dont just focus on effeciency, they also focus on pure power. While cost management is key in the logistics of managing a wartime econ, if you have access to a tool that can end the conflict sooner, than the price be damned - you use it. Ending the war itself is cheaper than the complex tool that gave the edge, always.

The Aerospike would he the go to for an Intra-Atmospheric fighter bomber. Simple as that. You match an aerospike with a combined cycle jet using something like an MHD Intake, and you have yourself a dream machine. This sort of thing will never EVER be a business practical idea, but then again - the Military itself is not a business.

Hence why I think aerospikes could see use in military applications, the one application where such a missiom profile actually fits the Aerospikes performance niche.
Seems to me that linear aero spike would be fairly simple to replace an ablative layer for cooling after each flight. It could even be carbon 3D printed with integral channels for cooling.

A combination of the bell and spike. Overall form would be similar to the bell but with the spikes advantages. From the throat to the end of the bell, but not a bell exactly, would be a ceramic nitrogen filled bladder. Narrow from throat to bell shape back to narrow but not quite as much. The exhaust would form a beam of gas traveling much faster than sound. The heat from the gas would recoil away from the bladder with an accelerated force. Just this traversal from the throat around the bladder would accelerate the gas to ultrasonic speeds. The pressure of the gas on exit would be exponentially greater than ambient. This design would be more fuel efficient and have greater thrust than any other by several fold. If this were combined with a plasma burn in vacuum, you could fly to the moon, land there, and fly back on a single tank of fuel. Just pulse charge the outer shell to maintain the plasma trajectory, and the bladder would do the same but even better with the increased temps of the plasma.

TL;DR: No, aerospikes are not better than bell nozzles. They have a higher average efficiency, but a lower peak efficiency. Higher average efficiency would be great if single-stage-to-orbit rockets were practical on Earth, but Earth's gravity makes SSTO rockets impractical due to the penalty of dragging unnecessary dead-weight into orbit after the rocket has burned through most of its fuel just to get off the ground. Since Earth's gravity favors the use of multi-stage rockets, each rocket must have a separate set of engines for each stage, so each set of engines can be optimized for the atmospheric pressure at the altitude it will operate. This means bell-nozzle engines' higher peak efficiency is more valuable in real life, compared to aerospike engines' higher average efficiency. Meanwhile, in an airless environment like the Moon (or almost-airless like Mars), you can just use a vacuum-optimized bell-nozzle engine starting at ground-level all the way into orbit -- a scenario which still favors bell-nozzle engines' higher peak efficiency. Aerospike engines would only be the better option on a planet with significantly less gravity that also mysteriously still has an atmosphere at least as dense as Earth's, such as Titan.

Launchwise, an aerospike only makes sense on a SSTO when your sea level engine needs to also work in space. The thing is, there is about to be another use case where having an aerospike could make sense: landing your second stage. Either your vac engines work all the way down to sea level or you use other engines to land.


Current plans for Spaceship have dedicated sl-engines for landing (on Earth), but that could also be accomplished by replacing the vacuum-optimized Raptors with aerospike variants.


The way I see this could work would introduce additional complexity because it involves having two different scales of combustion chambers. One vac engine would be replaced with a 1+3 – 1+6 arrangement of full+subscale Raptors, so that most of the bell of the central full-scale Raptor would be provided by the exhaust of the subscale ones around it and their plug/spike would essentially consist of the exhaust of the full-scale one.


This would cut down on the vac engine bell size and allow thrust vectoring by exhaust shaping without physical gimbaling, so there's that too.

I have an idea for a two stage system I will write up for the Journal of Irrepeatable Results. The first stage would take the big dumb first stage to its logical conclusion; it would be an air pressure powered water propellant rocket. That would be easy to engineer and finance because it would not need refractory materials and the complexity of most rocket engines, even relative to steam rockets. The first stage's job is simply to carry an upper stage up above the atmosphere. The top stage would basically be like a single stage to orbit upgraded by having vacuum engine propulsion. The terms  “hot” and “cold” are really just measures of relative heat, since everything warmer than absolute zero ( at -273.15 degrees C ) contains heat. It's a pretty wide-spread misconception that mach diamonds are a sign of inefficiency.  In any atmosphere (minus pure vacuum), you will always have mach diamonds.  Even If you perfectly match the  ambient pressure at the exit of a nozzle, after a short amount of time the exhaust will lose pressure and start to be squeezed in by the atmospheric pressure.  Another way to think about supersonic flow out of a nozzle is thinking of the ambient pressure as a tube that's surrounding the exhaust gas.  There is a boundary between the fast-moving gas and the low speed ambient atmosphere.  The exhaust will react or 'bounce' off the low speed ambient air and create show waves (mach diamonds).  The only true visual clue that an engine is performing at the ideal exit pressure is if the exhaust is travelling straight out the nozzle at the exit plane.  You really just want the nozzle exit plane to be right at the crest of the mach diamond chain.

Tim:

Since it seems that the biggest problem with the aerospike design is the thermal and weight issues imposed upon the spike or thrust ramp why not just eliminate them from the design? instead of using some kind of exotic material merged with a complicated and heavy cooling system, achieve the same thing by using a smaller chemical explosion encircled by the main injectors to duplicate what the spike or thrust ramp does? This would only add thrust without the adding any additional weight. It also would use the same fuel as the main engine and would not have the same heating concerns. Imagine having a small sea level type motor in the middle of a ring of additional injectors. As the atmospheric pressure reduces with altitude the plume of this center engine would expand. The outer combustion would press against this expansion causing it to elongate producing the same effect of having a longer spike enhancing the performance at higher altitudes. The aerospike is a good idea but they are trying to make it work by a mechanical means when a non-mechanical method should be used.

Yep. I watched it all.

does the TWR actually matter in that statistic? I mean, you rarely send an engine up to space by itself. It wouldn't even have fuel to do so. The number you quote here is "How much does it push versus how heavy is the engine" while the weight of the engine is only a tiny tiny amount of the total weight of even the dry vehicle without fuel.
A TWR based on engine weight is a useless stat in my opinion because it doesn't matter how many times it's own weight the engine can push. It matters how much it can push in total force.
A low TWR engine can still push more than a high TWR engine that is built with less metal.
If the engine weight would be a more substantial percentage of the total vehicle, it would become more relevant.

So Raptor has 107:1 ratio, which means it can push 107 times it's own weight. So (ballpark numbers) raptor weighs 200t(thrust)/107t(weight ratio) = 1.86t
Were raptor to weigh 6.66 tons, it would have a TWR of 30:1, which is the lowest of all the engines here.
It would still only weigh 5 tons more. That's 0.3% of the Mk1 total fuelled weight of 1400 tons (still not sure how they want to pull off pushing 1400 tons with 3*200 tons raptors but it's just an example)
The change from an Engine TWR of 107:1 to 30:1 by increasing raptor's own weight by 5t per engine results in a fuelled vehicle TWR change from (600/1400) 0,428:1 to (600/1415) 0,419:1
Rather insignificant.

I've been following the development of the Skylon spaceplane. Obviously, they won't be using an aerospike engine but I think they are considering a different form of altitude compensation called an expansion deflection nozzle on their SABRE engine.

It's basically similar to a traditional bell nozzle but with the addition of a centrebody or pintle which directs the exhaust gases along the outer wall of the nozzle.

As an SSTO, Skylon will have to overcome the problem of engine efficiency as it gains altitude so it'll be interesting to see if the ED nozzle can work while avoiding the problems of an aerospike and if the SABRE does fly, how it compares to the bell nozzle.

Thank you so much for this, I love this video especially and all the research and test footage you dug up. BUT... didn't you just skip over the main advantage of aerospikes in your comparison to bell nozzle rockets?
With a bell nozzle rocket, the thrust to weight ratio will always be half in a launch to orbit, since you will ALWAYS be carrying another set of bell nozzle rockets in your second stage that are just dead weight for half the trip. With an aerospike engine, you fly all the way to orbit with one engine, and then have the opposite issue, where in space you are lugging around a big empty fuel tank instead of jettisoning it... but does that even matter since you are floating around in space already?

Shouldn't the need for two entire sets of bell nozzle rockets in two stages, carrying dead weight inside the hardest lift phase from Earth with twice the number of moving parts, be the main comparison with an aerospike engine? Even if an aerospike engine was exactly the same performance of a bell nozzle rocket-- it would still be twice as good since you only need one of them.

Aerospikes are just part of the equation, the ideal system being an actively dynamic adjustable nozzle similar to how the Pratt and Whitney J58 engines controlled thrust distribution on the SR-71. This would negate multi stage nozzle requirements and provide better efficiency. As with modern combustion vehicles, dynamic systems such as Variable Valve Timing, Electronically Adjustable Velocity Stacks, Adjustable Exhaust Valves and Active Aero clearly demonstrate dynamic systems are the future to producing more power and efficiency. Current rocket nozzle designs are still very primitive and have a long way to go however this requires massive aeronautical research, significant engineering costs and further complexity which is the last thing we need right now. I'm convinced dynamic thrust systems are in store for the future beyond even what an Aerospike can offer and it's just a matter of time before these engineering challenges are solved.

Thanks for the video.. well done.. FYI, I have researched such altitude-compensating nozzles over the decades with various partners/teams, and one of the most serious problematic aspects we kept running into was the aerodynamic interaction between exhaust flow and slipstream.  There are very unstable and unpredictable side forces that can easily arise, especially when flying through jet streams, where angle of attack can suddenly increase, and fluctuate. Thrust Vector Control systems are very difficult to incorporate into such nozzle designs in general, but the magnitude of these suddenly shifting side forces are greatly amplified with aerospike-type nozzles, and were ultimately too great of a development risk for commercial LV programs.  Keep on doing what you do! ;)

Now for some interesting implications. So complexity (and therefore reliability) is a primary factor for issues with the aerospike. SpaceX seemingly has determined that a couple dozen-ish mass produced engines is the way to go. As an overall system, this is hugely complex (sort of), though they kinda make up for it with brute force (engine-out capabilities). It is no doubt a huge development risk, but it seems like a single (massive, this may compound thermal & mass issues) aerospike with a couple dozen-ish chambers would be similar total complexity.


Of course, there is only 1 rocket that has successfully proven out the many engined concept, so we are still in the early stages at this complexity level anywho! Another interesting note against aerospike when you consider SpaceX, is that Starship would still be less complex with traditional engines, so any actual parity in this way is limited to the booster, Superheavy.

Hi Tim, You have done a great job of explaining the importance of surface area to volume ratios and how they affect the 'ability' and 'inability' to cool the components comprising the rocket engine 'BEASTY'. Those relationships play out going in the other direction too. The case being Diesel engines. Here though, it's a case of HEAT LOSS. A Diesel engine relies on the temperature of compression to supply the necessary heat and temperature for the fuel to ignite when injected into the cylinder during the power stroke. A very large Marine Diesel engine has a smaller surface-area-to-volume ratio than a small Diesel engine like in the famous VW Diesel Rabbit. I believe the Rabbit had something on the order of a 22:1 compression ratio where very large Diesel engines can have a compression ratio as low as a 12.5:1 (or even less). The larger surface-area-to-volume ratio of the smaller Diesel engine results in HEAT LOSS to the engine's water jacket and head ...  thus the need for a much higher compression ratio to support the Diesel Cycle and by the very same exponential relationships you so perfectly explained.

The hot exhaust gas cools off the hotter exhaust gas just like adding 150 degree water to 200 degree water cools it down. If you only added heat, then the temperature would actually rise. But you aren''t just adding heat. You're adding matter as well. Temperature can be thought of like heat density, or heat divided by mass. When you add in that hot exhaust into the hotter exhaust, you're adding heat to the numerator, but also adding mass to the denominator.


With regular density (mass/volume), it's not just the mass or just the volume that matters, it's the ratio. So to get a given temperature, it's not just the heat or just the mass that matters, it's both. Adding ice cubes into a drink is technically adding some heat, but you're increasing the mass in the drink by a lot more than you're increasing the heat. So the temperature goes down.

Isn't the whole purpose of any rocket engine to provide maximum PRESSURE against the bottom of the rocket (via the inside of the combustion chamber and any attached bell), propelling it upwards? When you start with a simple, straight combustion chamber you get a certain amount of pressure. When you pinch off a section of that chamber then, sure, you get higher speed of the ejected gasses, but isn't the important effect that it increases the pressure inside the upper part of the combustion chamber? I still don't see why a straight chamber, no pinching, no bell, no supersonic flow, can't provide the best result.

Every description that I've seen explaining how rocket engines work deals basically with attaining maximum flow. What I'd really like to see are diagrams that show the pressures against the insides of the combustion chamber and bell, with one vector showing the pressure tangent to each surface and another vector showing the pressure in the direction you want the rocket to move. THAT would make it a lot clearer to me as to what effects things like the constricting nozzle and bell shape and size have on the thrust. I just think of the velocity of the exhaust as side-effects of maximizing those pressures.

The best thing about an aerospike is it makes a good heatshield.
Engine first re-entry for the first stage might make the aerospike worthwhile because then you probably wouldn't need to do an entry burn, which would probably make up for the extra weight.
I think the coolest aerospike cycle is probably an open expander cycle, its super simple, as efficient as a staged combustion cycle (maybe more in a truncated aerospike because of the base bleed), and unlike a closed expander it scales up well for large first stages. aerospikes are also really good for dual expander cycles because it keeps the fuel and oxidizer cooling tubes separate. a dual expander doesn't need any fancy seals on the turbines, even simpler. the dual expander also lets you burn the turbine exhaust on the base of the spike, so you get more pleasure and can truncate the spike even more.


For a real SSTO, a variable throat area is a must, because an engine big enough to expand to a vacuum expansion ratio is so heavy for the sea level thrust it can produce. The thrust required goes down as you go up anyway, so reducing the throat area and thrust instead of increasing the exit area to increase the expansion ratio seem like a much lighter weight solution. it also lets you maintain chamber pressure at low throttle, which is helpful later in the flight when you throttle down for structural reasons and lets the main engine actually do orbital maneuvering efficiently. Unless you want engine first re-entry, its variable throat expansion deflection nozzles all the way! It has a much smaller throat area and a much better combustion chamber than an aerospike, and expansion deflection nozzles are even lighter than even bell nozzles because they can be shorter for the same expansion ratio.

How to boil water to make a cup of tea, the easy way:

Start with 2 cups of water at 12.5 degrees Celsius. Pour both of them into a single pot. The water from both will mix together and the temperatue will now be 25 degrees. Now fill both original cups with this water that's in the pot. Then pour it back into the pot. The water in the pot now has 50 degreees. Repeat the process one more time, and voila, you have a pot of water at 100 degrees.

Guys why everyone is saying that rockets have extremely high velocities? NO! They have extremely LOW exhaust velocities compared to the speed of light, even much less than the orbital/escape velocity of earth. That’s why chemical rockets have terrible specific impulse

The reason the sum of hot gasses at 1000 degrees and 2500 degrees does not add up to 3500 and actually is the average of the two is that the "colder" gas at 1K temp has lower energy than the hotter gas at 2.5k temp and on mixing the colder is extracting energy (Read: Heat) from the hotter gas to achieve system equilibrium.

From equation standpoint to make it simpler, what you are mistaking it to be is:
T1 + T2 = T
What it actually is:
(M1)T1 + (M2)T2 = (M)T

Also, one interesting niche application for aerospike engines (or a related type of nozzle, the plug nozzle) is in nuclear-thermal engines. The plug body protects the core from micrometeoroids, while prevent neutron loss through the nozzle (you can make the core-facing surface out of a neutron reflector) and thus allowing you to make the reactor lighter/use lower-grade nuclear fuel for the same power level and runtime. It also, in combination with something called cascade vane thrust reversers (essentially deflector fins inserted into the exhaust stream) allows easy thrust vectoring, which with the in comparison to chemical engines quite a bit heavier and usually longer nuclear engine cores is harder, as well as thrust reversal and thrust neutralisation (no net thrust despite the engine still running), which is useful for rendezvous, which with nuclear rockets normally would be a bit complicated due to a) not being able to point your nozzle at the rendezvous targets and b) nuclear rockets being a lot more sluggish in their throttle response than chemical ones.

Regarding the feasibility of aerospike engines, I suspect that eventually someone will figure out how to figure out how to reduce the complexity of the combustion chamber, making them cheaper and more reliable.  This might be done by replacing the array of combustion chambers with one continuous chamber that runs the full length of the nozzle ramp.   I also believe that someone will improve the cooling issue though pumping fuel though the throat in a more effective and efficient way, combined with materials that handle higher heats, such as a titanium ceramic alloy of some type.  Additionally, by making the combustion chamber and throat from one piece, it would likely improve the surface area ratio to the fuel volume, helping with heat dissipation.  I also think that the fuel reaction percent could be improved by altering the combustion chamber shape, along with improvements to the injector arrays, that better mix the gases.  You could also use some sort of supersonic shock-wave design in the throat to get more of the fuel and oxidizer to combine, improving combustion efficiency.  My guess is that better computer modeling could help find ways to improve the shape and flow of the fuel from the injectors through the combustion chambers, and out the throat to achieve better performance and efficiency.  Better designs combined with 3D printing of advanced materials and alloys, all of these problems could be solved eventually.  It's just going to take a lot of advancements in computer aided modeling and design, materials engineering, and manufacturing processes to get there.

Tim, a better way to think of specific impulse is just as a proxy for exhaust velocity. Multiply ISP by G and you'll get the effective exhaust velocity in your preferred units of measurement (metric/imperial). ISP is standard anywhere that uses the same unit for seconds, so it is easy to compare Russian/US engines. However exhaust velocity is a much more intuitive measurement to use.

Great video, Tim. Learned a lot. I have a comment that relates to you statement in this video about SSTO sucking esp. the fact that even the best optimized single stage engine is still way less efficient over all than a multi-stage vehicle with atmosphere and vacuum optimized engines.
The best vehicle to get from the Earth's surface to a Martian orbit is not Super Heavy/ Starship. That system works great to LEO, but from there on it's like an SSTO. Wrong engine, for the job. There are vastly better methods of propulsion once your vehicle has achieved LEO, than any chemical rocket. The best (for many reasons) not the least of which is being able to utilize the enormous amount of free solar energy available in the inner to mid solar system. The water plasma engine. Cheap fuel- it's everywhere. High ISP- super high exhaust velocity and your fuel is easy to handle in the extreme.
No cryogenic hassles, it's not likely to blow up, it could be radiation shielding and could even be ballast to allow artificial gravity by rotating your vehicle around a common center with the payload on one end and your fuel on the other after your have achieved transfer velocity. Your could even decelerate into Martian orbit, so your deep space system would be waiting for a return trip. Momentus is commercializing water plasma thrusters for orbit change and station keeping and primary propulsion for deep space probes. Seems to me they could apply the same thrusters for powering something even larger, like Starship. Instead of just a tow truck between LEO and GEO that tow could be to anywhere in the solar system for any thing that could get to LEO!

You'd need a set of vacuum engines for the mars mission, but also carry an extra set of sea level engines just for landing. With aerospikes you could do all with just 1 set of engines and save some wheight. (Of course only if you can make them functioning reliable and if they have the same level of TVC capability)

16:40 you know how aircraft cabins are pressurized? well they're only pressurized at about 70-80% the atmospheric pressure at sea level. This is because increasing the presure further would put unnecessary strain on the fuselage.

When on your next flight do the following experiment: bring on board a plastic water bottle, drink the water and seal the bottle at cruise altitude and keep your eyes on the bottle as the aircraft descends for landing and th cabin is pressurized.
the results may surprise you.

If you're living in an area with tall mountains nearby (2000m or higher height difference from base) you can also replicate the experiment by sealing off the bottle on the mountain and bringing it back down. Tall mountains rising from low planes or at sea level are preferable.

Excellent video. Truely excellent.

the combination of the RS-2200 spec and the DEAN paper, suggest to me that it's kind of a matter of time before we see multi regime programs trying. Now that full flow staged combustion is proven to be workable (having a programatic reason to bring your engine back to earth definitely gives you an incentive to try and make the most effective engine you can, the RS25 is still very impressive and wouldn't have been developed for an expendable platform) there is some now technologically-accesible fuel efficiency on the table that can be blown on extra cooling if necessary. In 1999 they thought they "could" get the RS2200 light enough to get that 83:1 TWR, but only needed 75:1 to accheive SSTO you said. Comparing the TWR of the RS25 and the Raptor suggests that that's well within the realm of doable today. I think what I'm arguing in a round about way is that Space-X more than any other outfit to date, has a library of relevant proven technologies they could bring to bear on the problem and is one of the only concerns that legitimately has an incentive to try. And, materials science has moved on a lot in 20 years.
The rotary analogy is interesting, but even me as a huge fan of rotaries have to admit that the geometry of the combustion chamber just doesn't have the potential to provide the last word in efficiecy or torque, whereas an aerospike is sort of the opposite, it's a more complex machine with a potentially more efficient use of combustion chamber.

Take the boiling  glass of water at 100C and add a glass of water at 50 C. To reach an equilibrium the volume of 100 C will transfer its heat to the volume of 50C water.
